description: Animated maps and satellite images show the effects of the storm.
title: Mapping Florence’s Impact: Rainfall, Power Outages, and Wind
title_page: Mapping Florence’s Impact: Rainfall, Power Outages, and Wind - The New York Times
text:
Record amounts of rain have fallen in North Carolina since the outer edges of Hurricane Florence first reached the coast. The hurricane was downgraded to a tropical storm after it made landfall on Friday, but it continued to move slowly inland, dumping more rain on the Carolinas. For the latest updates on the storm, see our live briefing.
Source: National Weather Service
Power Failures Across the Region
More than one million customers lost power, mainly in North Carolina.
Customers without power, by county
Customers without power, over time Source: poweroutage.us . Note: Data do not include nine smaller utilities. The data also do not include about 70,000 customers of ElectriCities of North Carolina who have lost power since Friday. The utility did not provide information on when customers lost and regained power.
Where Winds Hit the Hardest
Sustained winds from the storm reached 85 miles per hour near the coast where Florence made landfall on Friday.

The Scale of the Storm
The storm brought an area of hurricane-force winds that stretched for 100 miles along the coast.
Composites of satellite imagery from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, via Charlie Loyd, Mapbox.
Where the Storm Is Headed
The storm weakened as it moved inland but continued to drop rain as it headed across South Carolina.
